newsitem.title: SRI LANKA: Sri Lanka prime lower after reserve ratio cuts - Central Bank.
newsitem.headline: Sri Lanka prime lower after reserve ratio cuts - Central Bank.

text.p: The average prime lending rate of Sri Lankan commercial banks has fallen sharply after the Central Bank twice cut reserve ratios since January, a Central Bank official said on Tuesday.
"The average prime lending rate is now 14.6 percent, down from an average of 18.4 percent in December 1996," R.A. Jayatissa, head of the Central Bank's Economic Research unit told Reuters.
He said the fall was due to lower cost of funds after the reserve ratio cuts.
The Central Bank slashed the reserve ratio by two percent points to 12 percent earlier this month, on top of a one point cut in January.
The two cuts released about 8.9 billion rupees into the system, Jayatissa said.
The move has also led to lower call money rates due to higher liquidity. Average call money rates have been at 10 percent since the cuts compared to an average 14 percent earlier, the official said.
